<sslproxy_foreign_intermediate_certs>Many origin servers fail to send their full server certificate chain for verification, 
assuming the client already has or can easily locate any missing intermediate certificates.[br]
Proxy service uses the certificates from this section to fill in these missing chains when trying to validate origin server certificate chains.
This section is expected to contain more PEM-encoded intermediate certificates.[br]
These certificates are not treated as trusted root certificates, and any self-signed certificate in this section will be ignored.
</sslproxy_foreign_intermediate_certs>

<OpenVPNClientCertNotRequired_explain>Don't require client certificate, 
client will authenticate using username/password only.[br]
Be aware that using this directive is less secure than requiring certificates from all clients.[br]
If you use this directive, the entire responsibility of authentication will rest on your authentication method.[br]
If you don't use this option, but you also specify an authentication method, then VPN server will perform double authentication.[br]
The client certificate verification AND the authentication method defined.</OpenVPNClientCertNotRequired_explain>

<activate_the_feature>Activate this feature</activate_the_feature>
<openvpn_mssfix_explain>Announce to TCP sessions running over the tunnel that they should limit their send packet sizes such that after VPN server
has encapsulated them, the resulting UDP packet size that VPN server sends to its peer will not exceed max bytes.[br]
The max parameter is interpreted in the same way as the Maximum Transmission Units parameter, i.e. the UDP packet size after encapsulation 
overhead has been added in, but not including the UDP header itself.[br]
Set to 0 disable the option
</openvpn_mssfix_explain>
<openvpn_fragment_explain>
Enable internal datagram fragmentation so that no UDP datagrams are sent which are larger than max bytes.[br]
The max parameter is interpreted in the same way as the Maximum Transmission Units, i.e. the UDP packet size after encapsulation 
overhead has been added in, but not including the UDP header itself.[br]
Thisoption option only makes sense when you are using the UDP protocol.[br]
It adds 4 bytes of overhead per datagram.
It should also be noted that this option is not meant to replace UDP fragmentation at the IP stack level.[br]
It is only meant as a last resort when path MTU discovery is broken.[br]
Using this option is less efficient than fixing path MTU discovery for your IP link and using native IP fragmentation instead.[br]
Having said that, there are circumstances where using OpenVPN's internal fragmentation capability may be your only option, 
such as tunneling a UDP multicast stream which requires fragmentation.
Setting to 0 disable the option
</openvpn_fragment_explain>
<parent_options_connect_timeout>This parameter specifies how long to wait (seconds) for a pending TCP connection to a parent.[br]
The default is 30 seconds.</parent_options_connect_timeout>

<APP_DARKSTAT_EXPLAIN>darkstat is a packet sniffer that runs as a background process,

<DarkStatNetwork>
Define a "local network" according to the  network  and  netmask addresses.[br]
All traffic entering or leaving this network will be graphed, as opposed to the default behaviour of only graphing traffic to and from the local host.[br]
[br]
Set here the local network to follow such as:[br]
192.168.0.0/255.255.0.0[br]
172.16.0.0/255.240.0.0[br]
10.0.0.0/255.0.0.0[br]
If you want to follow all networks, set 0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0
</DarkStatNetwork>

</signature_exclusions_explain>

<ClamaVDetectPUA>Detect Potentially Unwanted Applications (PUA)</ClamaVDetectPUA>
<ClamaVDetectPUA_explain>Activate the use of the PUA Database.[br]
The PUA database contains detection for applications that are not malicious 
by itself but can be used in a malicious or unwanted context.[br]
As an example: A tool to retrieve passwords from a system can be useful as long as 
the person who uses it, is authorized to do so.[br]
However, the same tool can be used to steal passwords from a system.[br]
Categories are:
[li]Some kind of runtime packer,[/li] 
[li]Password tools that can be used to recover or decrypt passwords for various applications.[/li]
[li]Applications that can be used to sniff, filter, manipulate or scan network traffic or networks.[/li] 
[li]Peer to Peer clients that can be used to generate a lot of unwanted traffic and sometimes it happens that copyrights are violated by downloading copyright protected content (Music, Movies) [/li]
[li]IRC Clients that can be a productivity killer and depending on the client[/li]
[li]Remote Access Trojans that are used to remotely access systems[/li]
[li]General system tools, like process killers/finders[/li]
[li]Keyloggers, spying tools[/li]
[li]Server based badware like DistributedNet[/li]
[li]Known problem scripts written in Javascript, ActiveX or similar[/li]
</ClamaVDetectPUA_explain>
<reconfiguring_antivirus>Reconfiguring Anti-Virus Daemon</reconfiguring_antivirus>

this is the reason that the web service listen on 80 and 443 ( mandatory ).[br]
To avoid certificate issue when an SSL site is blocked, you need to install the certificate on each browser</pdns_redirect_ssl_explain>

<transparent_ssl_explain>If checked TCP packets to the 443 port will be forwarded to the proxy.[br]
For logging purpose only ( SSL caching is not supported).[br]
By default the proxy will not decrypt SSL flow.[br]If you want to cache SSL sites or perform antivirus checking, you need to use SSL rules in order to force the proxy to decrypt the HTTPs protocol.[br]
[b]Caution: You need to install the proxy certificate in all browsers</transparent_ssl_explain>

<PROXY_ACLS>Advanced Web Proxy access rules</PROXY_ACLS>
<PROXY_ACLS_EXPLAIN>Web Proxy access rules is a feature that allows you to create advanced Web access rules based on HTTP protocol and network environments</PROXY_ACLS_EXPLAIN>
<new_acls_rule_explain>Set the type of rule you want to apply.[b]Allow access[/b] means that the request is allowed to be processed from the proxy service (except from the URLs filtering, Antivirus service ) and it bypass any authentication method.[br]
[b]Deny Access[/b] means that the request is denied directly from the proxy service and cannot be bypassed.[br]
After creating this rule, you will be able to add [b]Proxy objects[/b].[br]
Proxy objects will define how this rule will matches requests.
</new_acls_rule_explain>
<click_to_switch>Click to switch</click_to_switch>
<wizard_stats_apps_step1>Welcome to the Statistics Appliance connection wizard.[br]
This wizard will help you to connect your server to an Artica Statistics Appliance.[br]
This server will be designed to send real-time requests to a defined remote server.[br]
It can use 2 methods you must choose:[br]
The first one is to use [b]Syslog protocol[/b], this method is the best method for your server performance. Your server send real-time events directly to the statistics appliance.[br]
The statistics appliance will be able to parse sent logs and insert them to the statistics Database.[br]
If the connection is broken between the statistics appliance and your server, requests will be loss.[br]
The second one is to inject pre-processed events to the remote database located on the remote statistics servers.[br]
This method uses some CPU/memory of your server because events are pre-processed by your server.[br]
If a connection is broken between your server and the statistics appliance you will not lose events.
</wizard_stats_apps_step1>
<preprocessing_logs>Pre-processing requests</preprocessing_logs>
<your_partner>Your partner</your_partner>  
<activedirectory_explain_section>This section allows you to connect your system and your proxy service to your Active Directory service.[br]
In this case you will be able to silently authenticate users through the NTLM/Kerberos protocol.
</activedirectory_explain_section>
<wizard_kerberosntlm_explain>You can connect your proxy to your Active Directory using 2 authentication methods.[br]
[b]Use the NTLM standard method (join method)[/b] is compatible NTLMv2 and Windows XP or above.[br] 
[b]Use the Kerberos native method is the modern approach but not compatible with Windows XP and 2003.[br]
Both methods require:[br]
The time must be synchronized between Your Active Directory and this server.[br]
Your Active Directory must be resolved by this server.[br]
Your Active Directory must resolve your proxy server.[br]
Your server computer name cannot be longer than 15 characters due to netbios name limitations.[br]
</wizard_kerberosntlm_explain>

<dstdom_regex_explain>Matches the domain using a regular expression.[br]Example:[br]\.foo\.com[br]
^(([0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+)|(\[([0-9a-f]+)?:([0-9a-f:]+)?:([0-9a-f]+|0-9\.]+)?\])) - Matches an ip address in domain.[br]
A reverse lookup is tried if a IP based URL is used and no match is found. The name "none" is used if the reverse lookup fails.</dstdom_regex_explain>

<SquidCpuNumber_explain>By default the proxy use only one instance. This section allow you to create 
multiple proxy instances.[br]
Each instance should use it's own CPU in order to processing requests.[br]
The main proxy service will be in charge of load-balance requests between each CPU.[br]
Note that increase the number of instance could increase the machine load.[br]
[b]Do not use all available instances[/b] start smoothly with 2 instances and increase it after each test on production.
</SquidCpuNumber_explain>

<stemming>Stemming</stemming>
<stemming_explain>Stemming is a process which transforms inflected words into their most basic form.[br]
For example, flooring, floors, floored would probably all be transformed to floor by a stemmer for the 
English language.[br]
In many search engines, the stemming process occurs during indexing.[br]
The index will only contain the stemmed form of words, with exceptions for terms which are 
detected as being probably proper nouns (ie: capitalized).[br]
At query time, the terms entered by the user are stemmed, then matched against the index.[br]
This process results into a smaller index, but it has the grave inconvenient of irrevocably 
losing information during indexing.</stemming_explain>
<repair_table_explain>The table will be removed and re-created in orer to be repaired</repair_table_explain>

<NetCoreRmemMax>Socket send/receive buffer</NetCoreRmemMax>
<NetCoreRmemMax_explain>This sets the max OS receive or Send buffer size for all types of connections</NetCoreRmemMax_explain>
<TCP_Autotuning_settings>TCP Autotuning settings</TCP_Autotuning_settings>
<net_ipv4_tcp_mem_explain>Defines how the TCP stack should behave when it comes to memory usage</net_ipv4_tcp_mem_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpMemLow_explain>Tells the kernel the low threshold.[br] Below this point,the TCP stack do not bother at all about putting any pressure on the memory usage by different TCP sockets</NetIpv4TcpMemLow_explain>
<low_threshold>Low threshold</low_threshold>
<pressuring_memory>Pressuring Memory</pressuring_memory>
<NetIpv4TcpMemPress>Tells the kernel at which point to start pressuring memory usage down</NetIpv4TcpMemPress>
<NetIpv4TcpMemPages>Tells the kernel how many memory pages it may use maximally.[br]
If this value is reached, TCP streams and packets start getting [b]dropped[/b]
until we reach a lower memory usage again.[br] This value includes all TCP sockets currently in use</NetIpv4TcpMemPages>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemMin>Minimum Receive Buffer</NetIpv4TcpRmemMin>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemMin_explain>Tells the kernel the minimum receive buffer for each TCP connection,and this buffer is always allocated to a 
TCP socket, even under high pressure on the system</NetIpv4TcpRmemMin_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemDef>Default receive buffer</NetIpv4TcpRmemDef>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemDef_explain>Tells the kernel the default receive buffer allocated for each TCP socket</NetIpv4TcpRmemDef_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemMax>Maximum receive buffer</NetIpv4TcpRmemMax>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemMax_explain>Specifies the maximum receive buffer that can be allocated for a TCP socket</NetIpv4TcpRmemMax_explain>
<net_ipv4_tcp_wmem_explain>Holds information on how much TCP sendbuffer memory space each TCP socket has to use.[br] 
Every TCP socket has this much buffer space to use before the buffer is filled up.[br]
Each of the three values are used under different conditions.</net_ipv4_tcp_wmem_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemMin>Minimum TCP Send buffer</NetIpv4TcpWmemMin>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemMin_explain>Tells the minimum TCP send buffer space available for a single TCP socket.</NetIpv4TcpWmemMin_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemDef>Default buffer space</NetIpv4TcpWmemDef>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemDef_explain>The default buffer space allowed for a single TCP socket to use</NetIpv4TcpWmemDef_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemMax>Maximum TCP send buffer</NetIpv4TcpWmemMax>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemMax_explain>Tells the kernel the maximum TCP send buffer space</NetIpv4TcpWmemMax_explain>
<BBR_EXPLAIN>BBR (Bottleneck Bandwidth and RTT) is a relatively new congestion control algorithm written by software engineers at Google.[br]
It is the latest solution out of Googles persistent attempts to make the Internet faster via the TCP protocol  the workhorse of the Internet.[br]
The primary aim of BBR is to boot network utilization and reduce queues (that result into slow network activity)
</BBR_EXPLAIN>
<EnableSystemNetworkOptimize>Enable kernel network optimization</EnableSystemNetworkOptimize>
<kernelnetworkoptimization>Kernel network optimization</kernelnetworkoptimization>
<each_day>Each day at</each_day>

<firewall_configuration_file>Firewall configuration file</firewall_configuration_file>
<RsyncMaxcnx>The maximum number of simultaneous connections this service will allow.[br]
Any clients connecting when the maximum has been reached will receive a message telling them to try later.[br]
The default is 0, which means no limit</RsyncMaxcnx>

<ArticaAutoUpateRsync>If used, this server will synchronize installation sources from a remote Artica server in order to update Artica Core software</ArticaAutoUpateRsync>
<remote_synchronization>Remote synchronization</remote_synchronization>
<enable_remote_synchronization>Activate the remote synchronization</enable_remote_synchronization>
<writelonly_rsync>This parameter determines whether clients will be able to download files or not.[br]
If "write only" is activated then any attempted downloads will fail.[br]
If "write only" is disabled then downloads will be possible if file permissions on the daemon side allow them.[br]
The default is for this parameter to be disabled</writelonly_rsync>
<list_rsync>This parameter determines whether this module is listed when the client asks for a listing 
of available modules.[br]
In addition, if this is disabled, the daemon will pretend the module does not exist 
when a client denied by "hosts allow" or "hosts deny" attempts to access it.[br]
Realize that if "reverse lookup" is disabled globally but enabled for the module, 
the resulting reverse lookup to a potentially client-controlled DNS server may still 
reveal to the client that it hit an existing module.[br]
The default is for modules to be listable.</list_rsync>
<new_shared_folder>New shared folder</new_shared_folder>
<rsync_host_allow_explain>This section allows you to specify a list that are matched against a connecting client's hostname and IP address.[br]
If none of the patterns match, then the connection is rejected.[br]
Each pattern can be in one of five forms:[br]
[ul]
[li]A dotted decimal IPv4 address of the form [b]a.b.c.d[/b], or an IPv6 address of the form [b]a:b:c::d:e:f[/b].[br]
In this case the incoming machine's IP address must match exactly.[/li]
[li]An [b]address/mask[/b] in the form ipaddr/n where ipaddr is the IP address and n is the number of one [b]bits[/b] in 
the netmask.[br]
All IP addresses which match the masked IP address will be allowed in.[/li]
[li]An address/mask in the form [b]ipaddr/maskaddr[/b] where ipaddr is the IP address and maskaddr is the netmask in dotted decimal notation for IPv4, 
or similar for IPv6, e.g. ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:: instead of /64.[br]
All IP addresses which match the masked IP address will be allowed in.[/li]
[li]An [b]hostname[/b] pattern using wildcards.[br]
If the hostname of the connecting IP (as determined by a reverse lookup) matches the wildcarded name 
(using the same rules as normal unix filename matching), the client is allowed in.[br]
This only works if "reverse lookup" is enabled (the default).[/li]
[li]A hostname.[br]
A [b]plain hostname[/b] is matched against the reverse DNS of the connecting IP (if "reverse lookup" is enabled), 
and/or the IP of the given hostname is matched against the connecting IP (if "forward lookup" is enabled, 
as it is by default).[br]
Any match will be allowed in.[/li]
[/ul]
</rsync_host_allow_explain>

<RsyncReverseLookup>Controls whether the daemon performs a reverse lookup on the client's IP address to determine its hostname</RsyncReverseLookup>

<tproxy_method>Tproxy method ( aka Transparent Proxy )</tproxy_method>
<tproxy_method_explain>The Tproxy method is a Truly Transparent Proxy.[br]
The proxy needs to be in the direct physical path to be effective.[br]
The Transparent method hide the clients source IP/MAC addresses as the Tproxy method is able to transfert clients IP/MAC addresses.[br]
This method should made troubles if your final router is designed to be HTTP transparent too.[br]
If you plan to use MiKrotiK Firewall, you have to use this method.
</tproxy_method_explain>

if no interface is defined, then all interfaces will be hooked to catch requests and the Interface used to handle requests will be used to forward them to Internet.
</tproxy_interfaces_explain>

<udp_incoming_outgoing_address>These options are used by the [b]ICP[/b], [b]HTCP[/b], and [b]DNS[/b] modules (if enabled).[br]
Altering it will affect all of them in the same manner.[br]
The incoming interface is used for UDP packets received from other caches.[br]
The outgoing interface is used for UDP packets sent out to other caches.[br]
[b]Incoming interface and Outgoing interface can not have the same value since they both use the same port.[/b]
</udp_incoming_outgoing_address>

<artica_web_warning>[b]Warning[/b]: Use the 80/443 port for Artica Web administration interface is not recommended because you should encounter some Web interface issues when start/reload/restart proxy services.</artica_web_warning>
<rock_explain_form>The rock cache has a great potential because it supports sharing a single cache between multiple workers. It's the last piece that makes the sharing between workers complete.[br]
All the cached objects are stored in a single sparse file as a kind of database.[br]
Since rock cache is implemented as a separate process, it becomes a performance bottleneck unless you use Proxy's own shared memory cache to cache all objects.[br]
The default configuration of proxy only stores small objects in the memory cache, so it requires changing that limit and making the memory cache to be a large size.[br]
On the other hand when not using rock cache it works best to maximize use of the kernel file system buffers instead of proxy's memory cache for large objects
</rock_explain_form>
<swap_timeout>SWAP Timeout</swap_timeout>
<swap_timeout_explain>Proxy will not start writing a Cached object to or reading a cached object from disk 
if it estimates that the swap operation will take more than the specified number of milliseconds.[br]
By default and when set to zero, disables the disk I/O time limit enforcement.[br]
Ignored when using blocking I/O module because blocking synchronous I/O does not allow Proxy service to estimate the expected swap wait time.
</swap_timeout_explain>
<max_swap_rate>MAX SWAP rate</max_swap_rate>
<max_swap_rate_explain>Artificially limits disk access using the specified I/O rate limit.[br]
Swap out requests that would cause the average I/O rate to exceed the limit are delayed.[br]
Individual swap in requests (i.e., HITs or READs) are not delayed, but they do contribute 
to measured swap rate and since they are placed in the same FIFO queue as swap out requests, 
they may wait longer if this value is smaller.[br]
This is necessary on file systems that buffer "too many" writes and then start blocking proxy and other processes while committing those writes to disk.[br]
Usually used together with SWAP Timeout to avoid excessive delays and queue overflows when disk demand exceeds available disk "bandwidth". [br]
By default and when set to zero, disables the disk I/O rate limit enforcement.
</max_swap_rate_explain>
<lower_disk_speed>Lower speed disk</lower_disk_speed>
<normal_disk_speed>Normal disk speed (SATA)</normal_disk_speed>
<high_disk_speed>High disk speed (SSD)</high_disk_speed>
<central_cache>Central Cache</central_cache>
<build_new_cache>Building new cache</build_new_cache>
<max_memory_pages>MAX memory pages</max_memory_pages>
<tcp_time_wait_reuse>TCP time wait reuse</tcp_time_wait_reuse>
<tcp_time_wait_reuse_explain>In case of TIME WAIT problems, enable this option allow the TCP time wait port reusage.[br]
It is considered safe but may cause problems while dealing with some Firewalls or Load-balancers.</tcp_time_wait_reuse_explain>
<tcp_fin_timeout>TCP fin timeout</tcp_fin_timeout>
<tcp_fin_timeout_explain>
[b]Default value: 60 seconds[/b][br]
During this TIME_WAIT state, reopening the connection to the client costs less than establishing a new connection.[br]
By reducing the value of this entry.TCP/IP can release closed connections faster, making more resources available for new connections.
</tcp_fin_timeout_explain>
<tcp_time_wait_recycle>TCP time wait recycle</tcp_time_wait_recycle>
<tcp_time_wait_recycle_explain>
Activate TCP time wait port recycle (default disabled).[br]
It is considered sage but may cause problems with services not being able to distinguish clients behind NAT.[br]This option is more agressive than the TCP time wait reuse.[br] We suggest to not use this option if your Artice server is communicate directly with Internet or using NAT
</tcp_time_wait_recycle_explain>
<refresh_system_information-system>Refresh system information</refresh_system_information-system>

<WAN_CLIENT>Wan Compressor Client</WAN_CLIENT>
<wanproxy_client_mode>The Proxy compressor in client mode is able to send TCP traffic to a Proxy Compressor client.[br]In this mode, the proxy service use the local Proxy compressor client to send requests through Internet.</wanproxy_client_mode>
<auto_gzip>Automatic Gzip</auto_gzip>
<APP_ZIPROXY_ABOUT>The HTTP Compression service is a parent proxy, non-caching, compressing, HTTP proxy server targeted for traffic optimization.[br]
HTTP Compression service works by [b]recompressing[/b] pictures (such as JPEG, GIF, PNG, JPEG 2000), gzipping text and HTML/JS/CSS data optimization.[br]
Additionally it offers latency reduction by preemptive name resolution.[br]
Further functionalities of compression are supplied by means of optimization of code, named HTMLopt, CSSopt and JSopt (HTML/CSS/JS) which are analogous with Minification (programming).
This service is implemented as Parent proxy on for [b]HTTP[/b], the SSL is not optimized.
</APP_ZIPROXY_ABOUT>
<DisableSquidRealtimeLogs>Disable logging on the proxy</DisableSquidRealtimeLogs>
<DisableSquidRealtimeLogs_explain>If enabled, the proxy will no write requests events on disk.[br]
This feature safe performance and can be used when using a parent proxy that able to write events.
</DisableSquidRealtimeLogs_explain>

<shared_memory_locking_disable>Disable Shared memory locking</shared_memory_locking_disable>
<shared_memory_locking_disable_explain>Whether to ensure that all required shared memory is available by "locking" that 
shared memory into RAM when proxy service starts.[br]The alternative is faster startup time followed by slightly slower performance and, if not enough RAM is actually available during runtime, mysterious crashes.[br]
[b]Multiple processors feature[/b] uses many shared memory segments.[br]
These segments are brought into proxy memory space using an mmap system call.[br]
During the proxy startup, the mmap() call often succeeds regardless of whether the system has enough RAM.[b]
In general, the proxy service cannot tell whether the kernel applies this "optimistic" memory allocation policy (but popular modern kernels usually use it).
</shared_memory_locking_disable_explain>
<squid_purge_disabled_explain>Statistics of cached objects is disabled.[br]
This feature is able to extract all caches information in order to display stored websites.[br]
It consume many server performance. If you activate this feature, set the right schedule in order to not alter the production.
</squid_purge_disabled_explain>

<APP_PDNS_EXPLAIN>PowerDNS Authoritative Nameserver is a strong and versatile nameserver.[br]
The Authoritative Server will answer questions about domains it knows about, 
but will not go out on the net to resolve queries about other domains.[br]
When the Authoritative Server answers a question, it comes out of the database, 
and can be trusted as being authoritative.[br]
There is no way to pollute the cache or to confuse the daemon.
</APP_PDNS_EXPLAIN>
<APP_PDNS_RECURSOR_EXPLAIN>The PowerDNS Recursor, conversely, by default has no knowledge of domains itself,
but will [b]always consult other authoritative servers[/b] to answer questions given to it.[br]
If you need to resolve [b]Internet Hosts[/b] you must install this service.
</APP_PDNS_RECURSOR_EXPLAIN>
<backup_powerdns_database>Backup your DNS database</backup_powerdns_database>
<backup_powerdns_database_explain>This task backup all DNS entries saved in your database in order to restore them.[br]
if you need to retrieve backup containers, check the Legal logs backup features ( a valid Enterprise license is needed)</backup_powerdns_database_explain>
<MaxCacheEntries>Max Cache entries</MaxCacheEntries>
<PowerDNSMaxCacheEntries>Maximum number of entries in the query cache.[br]
1 million (the default) will generally suffice for most installations</PowerDNSMaxCacheEntries>
<MaxPacketCacheEntries>Max Packet Cache Entries</MaxPacketCacheEntries>
<PowerDNSMaxPacketCacheEntries>Maximum number of entries in the packet cache.[br]
1 million (the default) will generally suffice for most installations</PowerDNSMaxPacketCacheEntries>
<PowerDNS-allow-from>
Netmasks (both IPv4 and IPv6) that are allowed to use the server.[br]
The default allows access only from RFC 1918 private IP addresses.[br]
Due to the aggressive nature of the internet these days, it is highly recommended 
to not open up the recursor for the entire internet.[br]
Questions from IP addresses not listed here are ignored and do not get an answer.
</PowerDNS-allow-from>
<pdns_network_item_add>Add a single address with /32 mask ( 192.168.1.1/32 ) or the full network with the CDIR mask ( eg 192.168.1.0/24 ) if you want to define any network, add 0.0.0.0/0</pdns_network_item_add>
<PowerDNS-allow-from-default>The default allows access only from RFC 1918 private IP addresses: [b]192.168.0.0/16, 10.0.0.0/16, 127.0.0.0/8, 172.16.0.0/12[/b]</PowerDNS-allow-from-default>

<SOA_NAME_EXPLAIN>This is the name that this record will have in the DNS, you will use this name to identify your record</SOA_NAME_EXPLAIN>
<DNS_TTL_EXPLAIN>The number of seconds that this record will be cached in other servers</DNS_TTL_EXPLAIN>
<SOA_COMPUTER_EXPLAIN>The FQDN of the name server that was the original or primary source of data for this zone.</SOA_COMPUTER_EXPLAIN>
<DNS_SOA_SERIAL_EXPLAIN>The starting serial number (the number version of your zone / domain).[br] If you apply this SOA to a domain that is already created, the serial number will be incremented by one</DNS_SOA_SERIAL_EXPLAIN> 
<SOA_REFRESH_EXPLAIN>The time interval (in seconds) before the zone should be refreshed. Recommended value -- 86400 (24 Hours)</SOA_REFRESH_EXPLAIN>
<SOA_RETRY_EXPLAIN>The time interval (in seconds) before a failed refresh should be retried. Recommended value -- 7200 (2 Hours)</SOA_RETRY_EXPLAIN>
<SOA_EXPIRE_EXPLAIN>The time internal (in seconds) that specifies the upper limit on the time internal that can elapse before the zone is no longer authoritative. This is when the secondary name servers will expire if they are unable to refresh. Recommended value -- up to 2419200 (672 Hours)</SOA_EXPIRE_EXPLAIN>
<SOA_NEG_EXPLAIN>The amount of time a record not found is cached.[br]Recommended values can vary, between 180 and 172800 (3 min -- 2 days)</SOA_NEG_EXPLAIN>
<SOA_EMAIL_EXPLAIN>Email address of the administrator responsible for this zone.[br]
(As usual, the email address is encoded as a name.[br]
The part of the email address before the @ becomes the first label of the name;[br]
the domain name after the @ becomes the rest of the name.[br]
In zone-file format, dots in labels are escaped with backslashes; thus the email address john.doe@example.com would be represented in a zone file as john\.doe.example.com.)
</SOA_EMAIL_EXPLAIN>
<negative_cache>Negative cache</negative_cache>
<NS_RECORD_EXPLAIN>These records indicate which name servers are authoritative for the zone / domain.[br]
NS Records are primarily used if you want to break your domain into subdomains.[br]
Subdomains indicate you are delegating a portion of a domain name to a different group of name servers.
</NS_RECORD_EXPLAIN>
<SOA_RECORD_EXPLAIN>A Start of Authority record (abbreviated as SOA record) is a type of resource record in the Domain Name System (DNS) containing administrative information about the zone, especially regarding zone transfers.</SOA_RECORD_EXPLAIN>

<PDNS_MASTER_EXPLAIN>When operating as a master, PowerDNS sends out notifications of changes to slaves, 
which react to these notifications by querying PowerDNS to see if the zone changed, 
and transferring its contents if it has.[br]Notifications are a way to promptly propagate zone changes to slaves, 
as described in RFC 1996</PDNS_MASTER_EXPLAIN>

<DNSSEC>Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC)</DNSSEC>
<DNSSEC_ABOUT>The Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC) is a suite of Internet Engineering 
Task Force (IETF) specifications for securing certain kinds of information provided by the Domain Name System (DNS) as used on Internet Protocol (IP) networks.[br]
It is a set of extensions to DNS which provide to DNS clients (resolvers) origin authentication of DNS data,
authenticated denial of existence, and data integrity, but not availability or confidentiality.</DNSSEC_ABOUT>

<WELCOME_4_1>Artica is an open source software with a [b]Community Edition[/b] and an [b]Enterprise Edition[/b] that requires a license but provides advanced features.[br]
If you plan to use only the Community Edition ( Free of charge ), Click on [b]Use only the Community Edition[/b] button.[br]
In this case, Artica will hide all Enterprise features and let you playing only with Community features.[br]
</WELCOME_4_1>
<use_community_edition>Use the Community Edition</use_community_edition>
<use_enterprise_edition>Use the Enterprise Edition</use_enterprise_edition>
<WELCOME_4_2>Success! Your are now the owner of an Artica server is Community Edition.[br]
The Community Edition allows you to use this appliance for an unlimited time and for an unlimited users.[br]
[b]All Entreprise features are hidden[/b].[br]
If you want to turn your Appliance to an Enterprise Edition, just run this wizard again by using the link in the License section.[br]
Now you have to choose which service you want to install on this server.[br]
Click on the [b]Features[/b] button in order to build services.
</WELCOME_4_2>
<WELCOME_4_3>The Entreprise edition allows you to use dedicated feature for Enterprise.[br]
In order to get a trial period for 30 days or to receive you Enterprise License, fill this form.[br]
You will receive a [b]confirmation eMail[/b] from our Artica team.[br]
This message will confirm that your server can be activated to an Enterprise Edition server.[br]
When the license is expired, your server will return automatically to a community edition server.
</WELCOME_4_3>
<WELCOME_4_4>You using the Artica in Community Edition.[br]
The Community Edition allows you to use this appliance for an unlimited time and for an unlimited users without Enterprise features.[br]
If you need to turn to [b]Enterprise Edition[/b] click on the wizard button.
</WELCOME_4_4>

<locales>Locales</locales>
<LOCALES_EXPLAIN>
A locale is a set of parameters that defines the user's language, 
region and any special variant preferences that the user wants to see in their user interface.[br]
Usually a locale identifier consists of at least a language identifier and a region identifier.[br]
These settings usually include the following display (output) format settings:[br]
Number format setting[br]
Character classification, case conversion settings[br]
Date-time format setting[br]
String collation setting[br]
Currency format setting[br]
Paper size setting[br]
other minor settings ...[br]
</LOCALES_EXPLAIN>

<ip_reputation>IP reputation</ip_reputation>
<postfix_ip_reputation_explain>IP reputation allows you to link your SMTP service to a DNS black database.[br]
When SMTP servers are connected to your service, it checks the IP address on these services.[br]
If the IP address is listed, then the connection is [b]rejected[/b] and the SMTP server is not able to send messages.
</postfix_ip_reputation_explain>

<articatech_rbl>Artica reputation database</articatech_rbl>
<articatech_rbl_explain>Artica reputation database is a database of 2.500.000 blacklisted ( more than 10.000 whitelisted ) SMTP servers IP addresses.[br]
It is designed to increase the SPAM detection rate by rejecting advertising SMTP services, home users range addresses...
</articatech_rbl_explain>

<APP_RBLDNSD_HOWTO>
To build this service, you must create a DNS zone (subdomain) in your main DNS server for [b]rbl.mydomain.com[/b] and point it to your Artica server.[br]
; subdomain delegation[br]
[br]rbl.mydomain.com.  in ns rbl.mydomain.com.
[br]rbl.mydomain.com.  in a 101.102.103.104[br]
if you blacklisted IP 89.40.1.32[br]
then doing a regular DNS lookup like this:[br]
nslookup test.rbl.mydomain.com[br]
nslookup 32.1.40.89.rbl.mydomain.com[br]
should result in a match of [b]127.0.0.2[/b]
</APP_RBLDNSD_HOWTO>

<servernames>Server names</servernames>
<servernames_explain>
Server names determine which server block is used for a given request.[br]
They may be defined using exact names, wildcard names, or regular expressions.[br]
Examples:[br]
[b]example.org[/b][br]  
[b]www.example.org[/b][br]
[b]*.example.org[/b][br]
[b]mail.*[/b][br]
[b]192.168.1.1[/b][br]
[b]~^(?<user>.+)\.example\.net$[/b][br]
When searching for a virtual server by name, if name matches more than one of 
the specified variants, e.g. both wildcard name and regular expression match, 
the first matching variant will be chosen, in the following order of precedence:[br]
exact name[br]
longest wildcard name starting with an asterisk, e.g. *.example.org[br]
longest wildcard name ending with an asterisk, e.g. mail.*[br]
first matching regular expression (in order of appearance)[br]
</servernames_explain>

<APP_MYSQL_ABOUT>MySQL is an open-source relational database management system (RDBMS).[br]The MySQL development project has made its source code available under the terms of the GNU General Public License, as well as under a variety of proprietary agreements.[br]
MySQL was owned and sponsored by a single for-profit firm, the Swedish company MySQL AB, now owned by Oracle Corporation.[br]
For proprietary use, several paid editions are available, and offer additional functionality.</APP_MYSQL_ABOUT>
<APP_GREENSQL_ROUTER_ABOUT>
What is a GreenSQL Router?[br]GreenSQL router is the heart of the GreenSQL Database Firewall.[br] 
A router is an object used to connect queries from the frontend to a specific backend server.[br]
 Before passing the query to the backend, it will be processed by GreenSQL to determine if it is malicious and if so how it should be handled (block, alert, pass).
</APP_GREENSQL_ROUTER_ABOUT>

<GREENSQL_DB_ABOUT>Database names coincide to the names of databases on the backend SQL server.[br]
A database should be coupled with a GreenSQL Router[br]
A number of databases can use the same GreenSQL Router.[br]
You can edit the permissions for each database to block actions such as changes to DB structure, execution of sensitive commands
</GREENSQL_DB_ABOUT>

<ngx_bandwidth_explain>
You can configure the maximum download or upload speed for TCP connections.[br]
With these settings a client can download data through a single connection at a maximum 
speed of xx kilobytes per second, and upload data through a single connection at 
a maximum speed of yy kilobytes per second.[br]
However, the client can open several connections.[br]
So if the goal is to limit overall speed of loading for each client, 
the number of connections must also be limited to 1 in {limit_connections_ip} field.
</ngx_bandwidth_explain>

<explain_http_proxy_router_mode>The router mode is designed to transform the proxy service into a single HTTP/HTTPS Layer 7 router with limited features.[br]
This to avoid I/O and CPU consumption (all logging are disabled, no filtering plugins are used, no caching on disks....).[br]
Useful used if you dedicate your Artica server to be a simple router/Firewall.

<APP_MULTIPATH_TCP>MultiPath TCP Kernel</APP_MULTIPATH_TCP>
<already_installed>Already installed</already_installed>
<APP_MULTIPATH_TCP_EXPLAIN>
MultiPath TCP Kernel allowing a Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) connection to use 
multiple paths to maximize resource usage and increase redundancy.[br]
The redundancy offered by Multipath TCP enables inverse multiplexing of resources, and thus increases TCP throughput to the sum of all available link-level channels instead of using a single one as required by plain TCP.[br]
Multipath TCP is backward compatible with plain TCP.[br]
IT is particularly useful in the context of multiple networks (using both Wi-Fi and a mobile network is a typical use case).[br]
It also brings performance benefits in datacenter environments.[br]
In contrast to Ethernet channel bonding using 802.3ad link aggregation, It can balance a single TCP connection across multiple interfaces and reach very high throughput.
</APP_MULTIPATH_TCP_EXPLAIN>
<collapse>Collapse</collapse>
<never_direct_label>And force the use of a parent proxy for all requests (include SSL)</never_direct_label>
<never_direct_explain_no>But do not force the use of a parent proxy for all requests ( SSL for example)</never_direct_explain_no>

This often helps to reduce the size of transmitted data by half or even more.</enable_gzip_compression_explain>

</new_acls_rule_header_explain>

<APP_DNSFILTERD_EXPLAIN>DNS Filter feature allows you to create rules that are able to modify DNS answers according 
domain categories.[br]If the requested resolution matches a denied category then the DNS service will answer a "fake" IP address.[br]
 In this case, the Web server will not be available..
</APP_DNSFILTERD_EXPLAIN>
<APP_DNSFILTERD>DNS Filter service</APP_DNSFILTERD>
<APP_DNSFILTERD_REST>DNS Filter REST API service</APP_DNSFILTERD_REST>

<display_members>Display members</display_members>
<DNSFILTERD_SOURCES_EXPLAIN>
You can set here IP addresses that make DNS requests:[br]
A single IPv4 address: 10.4.2.240[br]
A CDIR notation: 10.0.0.0/16[br]
A Range of IPv4 addresses: 10.4.2.0 - 10.5.9.25
</DNSFILTERD_SOURCES_EXPLAIN>
<apply_dnsfiltering_rules>Apply DNS Filtering rules</apply_dnsfiltering_rules>
<ipaddr_on_blocked_domains>TCP/IP address on blocked domains</ipaddr_on_blocked_domains>
<DNS_FILTERING>DNS Filtering</DNS_FILTERING>
<dnsfilterd_white_explain>You can exclude from the DNS filtering {client_source_ip_address} using CDIR, or IP Adresse such as 192.168.1.0/24,192.168.1.1 or destination domain.[br]
When whitelisting a destination domain, the engine matches for with every domain part of the
requested name. So, if www.domain.com is requested, the extension checks whether www.domain.com, domain.com or .com is listed.
</dnsfilterd_white_explain>
<dnsfilterd_black_explain>You can globally deny from the DNS filtering {client_source_ip_address} using CDIR, or IP Adresse such as 192.168.1.0/24,192.168.1.1 or destination domain.[br]
When blacklisting a destination domain, the engine matches for with every domain part of the
requested name. So, if www.domain.com is requested, the extension checks whether www.domain.com, domain.com or .com is listed.
</dnsfilterd_black_explain>

<update_auth_link>Update the Authentication Link</update_auth_link>
<create_auth_link>Create the Authentication Link</create_auth_link>
<authlink_explain>The Authentication link is a specific URL that allows you to enter into the Artica Web console management without posting your credentials.[br]
In this case, if you save the link in your bookmark, you will be able to quickly enter into the Artica.[br]
Pay attention that this URL should not be shared...[br]
If the link is not correct, Artica will sends a 404 Not found on the Authentication page
</authlink_explain>

<APP_3PROXY>Universal proxy server</APP_3PROXY>
<APP_3PROXY_EXPLAIN>The Universal proxy server is a proxy server dedicated to provide connection proxy for 
HTTP proxy server, FTP proxy server, SOCKS 4/5 proxy server, POP3 proxy server, SMTP proxy server, TCP Port mapping, UDP Port mapping.[br]
This service is not designed to perform caching and advanced ACLs but it is very useful for protocols routing because all protocols can be routed in transparent mode and can be logged.
</APP_3PROXY_EXPLAIN>

<ftppr>FTP proxy gateway service</ftpr>
<ftppr_explain>This service allows users to access to FTP servers when using any [b]any FTP client[/b][br]
Only cleartext  authentication is currently supported</ftppr_explain>
<proxypr>HTTP gateway service with HTTPS and FTP over HTTPS support</proxypr>
<3proxy_service_explain>
This universal proxy server can	be used	 to  provide internal users  wuth  fully controllable access to external 
resources or to provide external users with	access to internal resources.[br]
It is not developed  to  replace the [b]main Proxy HTTP/HTTPS Service feature[/b],but it can extend functionality of
existing cashing proxy feature.[br]
It can be used to route	requests between  different  types  of clients and proxy servers.[br]
Think about	it as application level gateway with configuration like hardware router has for network layer.[br]
It can establish multiple gateways with	HTTP and HTTPS proxy with FTP over HTTP	support, SOCKS v4, v4.5	and v5, POP3 proxy, UDP and	TCP portmappers.[br]
</3proxy_service_explain>
<on_interface>On network interface</on_interface>
<ftppr_default_destination>Its used if targed address is not specified by user.</ftppr_default_destination>
<smtpp>SMTP gateway service</smtpp>
<smtpp_howto>You can use any MUA (Mail User Agent) with SMTP authentication support.[br]
Set client to use this server as an SMTP server.[br]
[b]Address of real SMTP server must be configured as a part of SMTP username.[/b][br]
Format for username is username@server, where server is address of SMTP server and username 
is users login on this SMTP server.[br]
Login itself may contain @ sign.[br][b]Only cleartext authentication is supported,
because challenge-response authentication (CRAM-MD5, SPA, etc) requires challenge from server before 
the service know which server to connect.</smtpp_howto>
<sockspr>SOCKS 4/4.5/5 gateway service</sockspr>
<sockdpr_explain>You should use client with SOCKS support or use some socksification support (for example SocksCAP or FreeCAP).[br]
Configure client to use this server.[br]
SOCKS allows to use almost any application protocol without limitation.[br]
This implementation also allows to open priviledged port on server (if socks has sufficient privileges).
</sockdpr_explain>

<sourcelist_explain>
You can set here source IP addresses:[br]
A single IPv4 address: 10.4.2.240[br]
A CDIR notation: 10.0.0.0/16[br]
A Range of IPv4 addresses: 10.4.2.0 - 10.5.9.25
</sourcelist_explain>
<userlist_explain>Usernames are case sensitive</userlist_explain>
<targetlist_explain>
You can set here destination IP addresses:[br]
A single IPv4 address: 10.4.2.240[br]
A CDIR notation: 10.0.0.0/16[br]
A Range of IPv4 addresses: 10.4.2.0 - 10.5.9.25
And host names:[br]
Its possible to use wildmask in the begginning and in the the end of hostname, e.g. *badsite.com or *badcontent*.[br]
[b]Hostname is only checked if hostname presents in request.[/b] 
</targetlist_explain>
<targetportlist_explain>May contain ports (X) or port ranges lists (X-Y).</targetportlist_explain>
<commands_in_protocol>Commands in protocol</commands_in_protocol>
<3proxy_parent_explain>Proxies may be grouped.[br]
Proxy inside the group is selected randomly.[br]
If few groups are specified one proxy is randomly picked from each group and chain of proxies is created (that is second proxy connected through first one and so on).[br]
Weight is is a number between 1 and 1000 and used to group proxies.[br]
Weights are summed and proxies are grouped together untill weight of group is 1000
</3proxy_parent_explain>

<transparentport_explain>Define here destination ports that will be redirected to the service.[br]
On port per line.</transparentport_explain>
<transparentin_explain>Define here networks that will be redirected to the service 
when trying to connects to the specified destination ports.[br]
No network is defined means, redirect all addresses.[br]
[b]You cannot have both include and exclude rules on the same statement.[/b][br]
Possible values are:[br]
An ip address: 192.168.1.1[br]
A CDIR notation: 192.168.1.0/24[br]
</transparentin_explain>
<transparentout_explain>
Define here destinations networks that will be redirected to the service 
No network is defined means, redirect all destinations addresses.[br]
[b]You cannot have both include and exclude rules on the same statement.[/b][br]
Possible values are:[br]
An ip address: 192.168.1.1[br]
A CDIR notation: 192.168.1.0/24[br]
</transparentout_explain>

<excludetransparentin_explain>
Define here source networks which will be excluded from the service redirection.[br]
[b]You cannot have both include and exclude rules on the same statement.[/b][br]
Possible values are:[br]
An ip address: 192.168.1.1[br]
A CDIR notation: 192.168.1.0/24[br]
</excludetransparentin_explain>
<excludetransparentout_explain>
Define here target networks which will be excluded from the service redirection.[br]
[b]You cannot have both include and exclude rules on the same statement.[/b][br]
Possible values are:[br]
An ip address: 192.168.1.1[br]
A CDIR notation: 192.168.1.0/24[br]
</excludetransparentout_explain>

You can use it when your Artica server is a gateway and wants to redirect protocols to local {APP_3PROXY} in socks method or local {APP_SQUID} in SSL method.

<spam_header_item>Data in message header</spam_header_item> 
<spam_subrule_explain>The [b]Pattern[/b] textarea is a regular expression ( .*?@domain\.tld or [0-9]+-[A-z]+@domain\.tld ).[br]
You can group several expressions using the pipe and parentheses:[br]
(sex|porn|love|night|[0-9]+orn)[br]
the header field must be filled only if you choose [b]Data in message header[/b] in the rule type.[br]
[b]Special pseudo-headers[/b]
[b]ToCc[/b] can be used to mean the contents of both the To and Cc headers.[br]
[b]EnvelopeFrom[/b] is the address used in the MAIL FROM: phase of the SMTP transaction that delivered this message.[br]
[b]ALL:raw[/b] will return a pristine (unmodified) header section.[br]
</spam_subrule_explain>

<DnscryptProxyMissing>DNSCrypt Proxy Missing</DnscryptProxyMissing>
<APP_DNSCRYPT_PROXY>DNSCrypt Proxy</APP_DNSCRYPT_PROXY>
<APP_DNSCRYPT_PROXY_ABOUT>DNSCrypt Proxy provides local service which can be used directly as your local resolver or as a DNS forwarder, encrypting and authenticating requests using the DNSCrypt protocol and passing them to an upstream server.[br]
The DNSCrypt protocol uses high-speed high-security elliptic-curve cryptography and is very similar to DNSCurve, but focuses on securing communications between a client and its first-level resolver.[br]
While not providing end-to-end security, it protects the local network, which is often the weakest point of the chain, against man-in-the-middle attacks.[br]
It also provides some confidentiality to DNS queries.</APP_DNSCRYPT_PROXY_ABOUT>

<APP_DOH_SERVER_TEXT>DNS-over-HTTPS server is Domain Name System (DNS) resolution via the HTTPS protocol.[br]
 A goal of this service is to increase user privacy and security by preventing eavesdropping and manipulation of
 DNS data by man-in-the-middle attacks</APP_DOH_SERVER_TEXT>

<swap_label_explain>Swap space in Linux is used when the amount of physical memory (RAM) is full.[br]
If the system needs more memory resources and the RAM is full, inactive pages in memory are moved
to the swap space.[br] While swap space can help machines with a small amount of RAM, it should not be considered a replacement for more RAM.[br]
Swap space is located on hard drives, which have a slower access time than physical memory.
</swap_label_explain>
<add_swap>New Swap Space</add_swap>

<DNSOTLS_EXPLAIN>DNS over TLS (DoT) is a security protocol for encrypting and wrapping Domain Name System (DNS) queries and answers via the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol.[br] The goal of the method is to increase user privacy and security by preventing eavesdropping and manipulation of DNS data via man-in-the-middle attacks.
</DNSOTLS_EXPLAIN>

Each interface is hermetic and did not share its routing rules.
For example you can setup 2 network cards with the same network but using a different gateway....

<but_not_to>But not to</but_not_to>
<masquerade_whatis>IP Masquerade, also called IPMASQ or MASQ, allows one or more computers in a network without assigned IP addresses to communicate with the Internet using the Artica server's assigned IP address.[br]
The IPMASQ server acts as a gateway, and the other devices are invisible behind it, so to other machines on the Internet the outgoing traffic appears to be coming from the IPMASQ server and not the internal PCs.
</masquerade_whatis>

<max_download_rate>Max download rate</max_download_rate>
<global_limitation>Global limit</global_limitation>
<per_client_limit>Per client limit</per_client_limit>
<limitb_client>Limit bandwidth per client</limitb_client>
<form_bandwidth_explain>the bandwidth limitation is based on the Token Bucket algorithms.[br]Basically,you have a bucket with a bandwidth reserve and a refilling speed.[br]
The emptying speed will depend on the users download.[br]
If the user uses sensibly the connection, the bucket will refill faster than it empties it, so there will be no penalization.[br]
If the user start to empty the bucket much faster than the refilling rate, it will empty and then it will have to settle with just the refilling speed.[br]
For each bandwidth throttling rule you configure, you have two types of buckets available: network and per client.[br]
Each client will consume their personal buckets and everyone included in the matched rule will consume the network bucket.</form_bandwidth_explain>

Statistic reports are oriented to user and bandwidth control, [b]this is not a pure cache statistics generator[/b].It use flat files to store data.[br]
This feature is limited according it can took several hours to parse a log file more than 1GB of data..

<APP_OPENDMARC>DMARC email policy filter</APP_OPENDMARC>
<APP_OPENDMARC_EXPLAIN>
OpenDMARC implements the proposed DMARC specification for authentication of message and reporting of observed traffic.[br]
It provides a DMARC processing service for mail transiting a milter-aware MTA
</APP_OPENDMARC_EXPLAIN>
<SPF_DNS_HOWTO>
Set up SPF to prevent spammers from sending unauthorized emails from your domain.[br]
This type of spamming is called spoofing.[br]
[b]Sender Policy Framework (SPF)[/b] is an email security method to prevent spoofing from your domain by just adding a record in your public DNS.[br]
Set up the SPF record for your domain by adding a TXT record to your domain host.[br]
Adding the TXT record doesnt affect your mail flow.[br]
Use the text generated and replace [b]1.2.3.4,1.2.3.5[/b] by your mx1 and mx2 public IP addresses.
</SPF_DNS_HOWTO>
<verify_spf_entries>Verify your SPF record</verify_spf_entries>
<EnableMultipleOrganizations>Allow creating multiple organizations</EnableMultipleOrganizations>
<EnableMultipleOrganizations_explain>If turned to on, you will be able to create several organizations on the same LDAP structure.[br]For example,if you need to use Artica Mailbox server for several companies.</EnableMultipleOrganizations_explain>

<APP_PRADS>Realtime Asset Detection System (PRADS)</APP_PRADS>
<APP_PRADS_EXPLAIN>
PRADS is a Passive Real-time Asset Detection System.[br]
PRADS employs digital fingerprints to recognize services on the wire, and can be used to map your network and monitor for changes in real time.[br]
Real-time passive traffic analysis will also let you detect assets that are just connected to the network for a short period of time, since PRADS can glean useful information from every packet.[br]
PRADS  aims  to  be  the  one-stop-shop for passive asset detection, and currently does MAC lookups, TCP and UDP OS fingerprinting as well as client and service application matching and a connection state table.[br]
Various output plugins include logfile and FIFO and make PRADS a useful replacement for p0f, pads and sancp.[br]
PRADS was built from the ground up for a small footprint and modern networks with IPv6 and gigabits of throughput.
</APP_PRADS_EXPLAIN>

<traffic_shapping>Traffic shaping</traffic_shapping>
<traffic_shapping_explain>Traffic shaping is a bandwidth management technique used on computer networks which delays some or all datagrams to bring them into compliance with a desired traffic profile.[br]
Traffic shaping is used to optimize or guarantee performance, improve latency, or increase usable bandwidth for some kinds of packets by delaying other kinds.[br]It is often confused with traffic policing, the distinct but related practice of packet dropping and packet marking.[br]The most common type of traffic shaping is application-based traffic shaping.
</traffic_shapping_explain>

<opcache_memory_consumption>The OPcache shared memory storage size (MB)</opcache_memory_consumption>
<opcache_explain>Normally PHP scripts are compiled at runtime.[br]Part of the computing time is required to convert the code.[br]
With OPcache, this calculation is performed only once and the precompiled, machine-readable (calculated) script is stored in a cache.[br]
The script can be loaded from this cache at lightning speed if required.[br] In most cases this leads to considerable speed improvements.
</opcache_explain>

<hacluster_user_account>Create a dedicated user account for Active Directory connection and ensure on Properties/Account tab the Do not require Kerberos preauthentication checkbox is [b]Enabled[/b].[br]
[b]Make sure you have created a type A record for %HOSTNAME% in your Active Directory DNS service[/b]
</hacluster_user_account>

To activate your CGuard access:
Pour activer votre accs CGuard :
[br]1) Visit the following web page in order to get your CGuard key:[br]%uricguard%[br]
[br]2) After confirming your email address by clicking on the link sent by eMail, the website will display your CGuard key for your Artica server[br]

<webcopy_explain>WebCopy is a reverse proxy feature that takes the hassle out of maintaining a CMS.[br]
This feature allows the reverse-proxy to browse the entire destination website in order to make a local copy in a static version.[br]
In this way, when Internet users browse your website, they do not consult the web pages from your web server but from the reverse-proxy service.</webcopy_explain>

<chuuid_why>The unique identifier (%s) allows Artica to identify your server as a unique object in your network.[br]When you connect several Artica servers in a farm for example ( Load-balancing / cluster / fail-over ) it allows to identify each server by this key.[br]It is also used to identify your server to the license server.[br]This is why it is imperative that your server has this identifier and it must be unique.[br]When cloning a virtual machine, it is likely that this identifier is duplicated, you must then change it.[br]
[b]Warning: Changing the ID will break the license, you will have to reassign this server in the license web administration console on Internet[/b]</chuuid_why>

<ttl_cache_webfiltering_explain>If you are using web filtering, the client will cache requests sent to the web filtering service for a specified time.[br]This is to centralize the responses between the processes and avoid flooding the service.[br]If value is 1 second, cache is not used.</ttl_cache_webfiltering_explain>
